texts.shortText: Short, bushy, tough, dark olive-brown species with numerous erect axes emerging from a dense stoloniferous base. Fronds narrow and strap-shaped, with a distinct midrib and irregularly and strongly lobed, toothed and with undulating margins. Typically forms dense, bushy clumps in the mid-intertidal.
Clumps typically up to about 100 mm tall, blades about 3 mm wide.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Very common species within its range and often dominant in the mid-intertidal, where frequently restricted to growing on the backs of limpets or barnacles, where it can escape from the attention of grazers. 

Like other Gelidium species used as a source of agar. It is one of the most important commercially-harvested seaweeds in South Africa and hence its ecology and the optimal methods of harvesting have been researched in some detail (see references).
Individual tufts often include a mixture of sporophyte and gametophytes stages of the life cycle, as well as juveniles.
One of about 10 regional species in this genus, but distinguished by the flat, prolifically-lobed fronds.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 402).

Carter, AR & Anderson, RJ (1991). Biological and physical factors controlling the spatial distribution of the intertidal alga Gelidium pristoides in the Eastern Cape, South Africa. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 71(3), 555-568.

Rothman, MD, Anderson, RJ, Kandjengo, L & Bolton, JJ (2020). Trends in seaweed resource use and aquaculture in South Africa and Namibia over the last 30 years. Botanica Marina, 63(4), 315-325.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 273).
